questions.question: Question 1: What is the defined duration for the diagnosis of acute pericarditis?
questions.explanation:
Clinically, acute pericarditis is of <6 weeks duration. Pericarditis is the inflammation of the pericardial sac. This inflammation can lead to excessive 
secretion of the pericardial fluid leading to pericardial effusion. When the accumulation of fluid 
causes obstruction to the inflow of blood into the ventricles, it is called cardiac tamponade. Clinically, pericarditis is classified as: • Acute - < 6 weeks • Subacute - 6 weeks to 6 months • Chronic - > 6 months

Question 2: A 30-year-old man presented with low-grade fever and severe retrosternal chest pain for 1 
week. The pain got exaggerated on lying down and relieved on sitting up. On auscultation of 
the precordium, a grating sound was audible. Which of the given statements is false regarding 
this auscultatory finding?

options.c: Best heard with the patient in left lateral position
options.d: Loudest at the lower left sternal border

questions.explanation:
1010 
Sold by @itachibot In this patient, Low-grade fever, chest pain that got relieved on leaning forward, and 
characteristic auscultatory findings are suggestive of acute pericarditis. The grating sound heard 
on auscultation is a pericardial friction rub. Features of the pericardial rub: • Superficial scratchy/leathery/grating sound caused due to friction between the visceral and 
parietal pericardium • Best heard at end-expiration with the patient sitting and leaning forward • Very high-pitched sound best heard with the diaphragm of the stethoscope, at the lower left 
sternal border • Consists of three components corresponding to atrial systole, ventricular systole, and early 
ventricular diastole • Pathognomonic of acute pericarditis

Question 3: A young man presents to the medicine OPD with dyspnea, cough, and severe chest pain for 1 
week. Chest pain is pleuritic in nature. On examination, the apical impulse is not palpable 
and breath sounds are normal. Which of the following is likely to be seen in the ECG of this 
patient?

options.a: ST-segment elevations with a convex upward configuration
options.b: PR-segment depressions early in the disease progression
options.c: Reciprocal ST-segment depressions in all corresponding leads
options.d: T-wave inversions developing concurrently with ST-segment elevations

questions.explanation:
The above scenario is suggestive of acute pericarditis. PR-segment depressions are seen early in 
acute pericarditis. The ECG changes in acute pericarditis evolve through 4 stages - • Stage 1 - Generalized ST-segment elevation with upward concavity with reciprocal depressions 
only in aVR and V1 and PR segment depression. • Stage 2 - The ST segments return to normal • Stage 3 - Diffuse T-wave inversion • Stage 4 - ECG returns to normal in weeks or months ECG in acute pericarditis vs acute MI: Cardiac biomarkers are grossly elevated in acute-MI, whereas in acute pericarditis the elevation if 
present is only mild and indicative of epi-myocarditis causing myocyte necrosis. The ECG below shows acute pericarditis causing diffuse ST-segment elevations in leads I, II, aVF,

questions.question:
Question 4: 1006 
Sold by @itachibot Auscultation of a patient with pleuritic chest pain revealed a patch of dullness with increased 
vocal fremitus beneath the angle of the left scapula. What is this sign called?
questions.explanation:
A patch of dullness with increased vocal fremitus beneath the angle of the left scapula due to the 
compression of the base of the lung by the pericardial fluid is called Ewart’s sign. It is seen in 
pericardial effusion. Acute pericarditis is frequently associated with pericardial effusion. Option A: Auenbrugger’s sign is the bulging of the epigastrium in severe pericardial effusion. Option B: Moschcowitz’s sign is the abrupt transition in percussion from the lungs to the right 
heart border seen in pericardial effusion. Option C: Dressler’s sign is the dullness to percussion of the lower half of the sternum seen in 
pericardial effusion.

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following is not a component of Beck’s triad?
questions.explanation:
Pulsus paradoxus is not part of Beck’s triad. Pulsus paradoxus is seen in cardiac tamponade. 
However, it is not a part of Beck's triad. Beck’s triad is seen in cardiac tamponade and it includes: • Hypotension • Soft or absent heart sounds • Jugular venous distension Cardiac tamponade is the accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space significant enough to 
cause an obstruction to the inflow of blood to the ventricles. This reduces cardiac output and 
arterial pressure causing hypotension. This also causes a greater than the normal reduction in the systolic arterial blood pressure 
producing pulsus paradoxus. Pulsus paradoxus refers to the fall in systolic blood pressure >10 
mmHg with inspiration. Other causes of pulsus paradoxus include: • Massive pulmonary embolism • Tension pneumothorax • Severe obstructive lung disease • Hemorrhagic shock The echocardiography clip below shows the swinging heart sign, which is characteristic of cardiac 
tamponade. 1013 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 6: Which of the following is a differentiating feature between cardiac tamponade and tension 
pneumothorax?
questions.explanation:
The differentiating feature between cardiac tamponade and tension pneumothorax is breath 
sounds. The breath sounds are absent in tension pneumothorax while they are present in cardiac 
tamponade. The presence of hypotension, distended jugular veins, and muffled heart sounds (Beck's triad) 
suggest a cardiac tamponade. These features can also be seen in tension pneumothorax. Other 
clinical features pointing towards tension pneumothorax are absent breath sounds, hyper 
resonance to percussion, and shift of the mediastinum to the contralateral side. Heart sounds can be muffled by structures between the stethoscope and the heart, eg, adipose 
tissue deposition (obesity), fluid accumulation (pericardial effusion, pleural effusion), gas 
accumulation (pneumothorax, subcutaneous emphysema), soft tissue masses can lead to 
attenuation of heart sounds.

questions.question:
Question 7: An intern is asked to measure the blood pressure of a patient with cardiac tamponade. He/she 
should ask the patient to:
questions.explanation:
The patient with cardiac tamponade is asked to breathe normally to elicit pulsus paradoxus. In a patient with cardiac tamponade, both ventricles share an incompressible pericardial covering 
due to the fluid. As the right ventricle enlarges during inspiration, the interventricular septum 
bulges into the left ventricle, reducing the left ventricular volume. This results in reduced stroke volume and hence reduced systolic arterial pressure. As a result, there is a greater than normal (more than 10 mmHg) fall in systolic arterial blood 
pressure during inspiration, producing pulsus paradoxus. This cannot be elicited if the patient is holding his/her breath, taking long or shallow breaths. 1014 
Sold by @itachibot Pulsus paradoxus is also seen with effusive constrictive pericarditis, restrictive cardiomyopathy 
and right ventricular myocardial infarction.

questions.question:
Question 8: An RTA victim is brought with breathing difficulty. On examination, the following is noted. 
Which of the following JVP findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?

options.a: Absent x and prominent y descent
options.b: Prominent x and absent y descent

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario with hypotension, muffled heart sounds, and elevated JVP (Beck's 
triad) suggest a diagnosis of cardiac tamponade. The JVP finding most likely to be seen 
is prominent x descent and absent y descent. Note: JVP in constrictive pericarditis is characterized by prominent x and y descents.

Question 9: A patient with dizziness and breathing difficulty came to the emergency department. The ECG 
is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The ECG shows electrical alternans with sinus tachycardia. This along with the patient's 
symptoms suggests a likely diagnosis of cardiac tamponade. Electrical alternans is the beat-to-beat alternation in the ECG waveform. In cardiac tamponade, 
this is caused by the periodic swinging motion of the heart in a large pericardial effusion. 1015

Question 11: A young motorist sustained injuries in a road traffic accident. He was found to have fractures 
of multiple ribs anteriorly on both sides. Radial and femoral fractures were also present. On 
examination, the following was noted. What should be the immediate intervention?

options.c: Intercostal tube drainage on both sides

questions.explanation:
The presence of hypotension, distended jugular veins, and absence of heart sounds (Beck's 
triad) are suggestive of cardiac tamponade. An urgent pericardial tap needs to be done to relieve 
the tension on the heart chambers. Although these features could be seen in tension pneumothorax as well, the presence of adequate 
bilateral air entry excludes this diagnosis. Pericardiocentesis, also known as pericardial tap, can be performed with sub-xiphoid, parasternal, 
or apical approaches. The most common approach is a sub-xiphoid approach under 
echocardiographic guidance. Option A: Rapid blood transfusion is needed in massive blood loss indicated by hypotension. 
Although this patient presents with hypotension, it is most likely a result of cardiac tamponade. 
Although blood transfusion is indicated, it will be effective only when the pericardial tap 
decompresses the pericardium. Option C: Intercostal tube drainage is done in tension pneumothorax. The presence of adequate 
air entry bilaterally excludes this diagnosis. Option D: The fixation of femur fracture and femoral artery is not a priority here. The inability to 
palpate pulses distal to the fracture could be a result of hypotension. This needs to be explored 
only if the patient fails to improve after the pericardial tap and blood transfusion.

questions.question:
Question 12: You're an intern examining a patient in the ICU. While assessing the JVP, you notice a lack of 
fall during inspiration. Which of the following conditions would you not consider as a 
differential diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
A rise or a lack of fall in JVP with inspiration is known as Kussmaul's sign. It is not seen in cardiac 
tamponade. Normally, in inspiration due to the negative intrathoracic pressure and increased intrathoracic 
volume, the capacity of the right heart increases and the JVP falls. In conditions where the 
myocardium or pericardium is poorly compliant, it does not allow the right heart chambers to 
accommodate more blood and this fall is not seen. In fact, due to an increase in venous return 
during inspiration, the JVP might rise. This is called Kussmaul's sign. This is seen in: • Restrictive cardiomyopathy • Constrictive pericarditis • Massive pulmonary embolism • Right ventricular infarcts 1017 
Sold by @itachibot • Advanced cases of left ventricular systolic failure Kussmaul’s sign is not seen in patients with cardiac tamponade because even though the increase 
in pericardial pressure exerts an inward force compressing the entire heart during inspiration, the 
increase in negative intrathoracic pressure is still transmitted to the right side of the heart. This 
allows for an increase in blood flow to the right atrium. Therefore, the JVP falls as seen in normal 
conditions. Feature

Question 13: A 20-year-old man presents to the emergency department with respiratory distress and 
hypotension following a trauma. He has subcutaneous emphysema and there is an absence of 
air entry into the right side of the lungs. What is the next best step?

options.a: Mean pulmonary arterial pressure >20 mm Hg
options.b: Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure  25 mm Hg

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario of a young male developing respiratory distress with hypotension, 
subcutaneous emphysema, and unilaterally absent air entry is suggestive of tension 
pneumothorax. The immediate next step, in this case, would be needle decompression at the fifth 
intercostal space anterior to the mid-axillary line (as the patient is an adult). In children, the second intercostal space in the midclavicular line is chosen as the site for needle 
decompression. Needle decompression turns a tension pneumothorax into an open pneumothorax. It has to be 
followed by tube thoracostomy. An intercostal chest drain (ICD) tube is inserted in the triangle of 
safety, just anterior to the midaxillary line on the side of the lung injury. The site of insertion is 
the same in both children and adults. The triangle of safety is bounded by the lateral border of the pectoralis major anteriorly, the 
anterior border of the latissimus dorsi posteriorly, and the fifth intercostal space inferiorly, with 
the apex below the axilla. This provides a safe landmark for the insertion of an ICD with minimal 
risk of tissue injury. 1018 
Sold by @itachibot Tension pneumothorax is a condition where air accumulates in the pleural space due to a one-way 
valve air leak, leading to the collapse of the affected lung. This can cause a mediastinal shift, 
compression of the opposite lung, and decreased venous return, resulting in obstructive shock. It 
commonly occurs during positive-pressure mechanical ventilation, but can also happen after chest 
trauma, subclavian/internal jugular venous catheter insertion, or chest wall defects. The diagnosis 
is clinical, and immediate treatment is necessary without waiting for radiological confirmation. Tension pneumothorax is characterized by chest pain, tachypnoea, tachycardia, hypotension, 
tracheal deviation away from the side of injury, absent breath sounds on the affected side, 
cyanosis, and neck vein distention. Patients can also develop subcutaneous emphysema as a 
complication secondary to the pneumothorax. 1019 
Sold by @itachibot Pulmonary Hypertension
